title: Wall Mounted TV component and cable management

description.text:
Full-motion TV Wall Mounting of large Flat Screen TV presents issues when accessories are also expected to be mounted to the back of the TV. In my case these add on elements were initially attached with adhesive Velcro fastener tapes that after a few months began to fail. In addition the wires were fastened using ratchet ties that in the end were difficult to adjust.

To address these issues I printed several clips that attached to the TV mount bracket to hold the accessories and cables very close to the back of the TV. This mounting improved the appearance and ease of service of the components.

The files here are designed specifically for a particular mount but using the OpenSCAD source file provided the shape of other TV mounts could be adapted.

Items that are carried on the back of the TV are:
Satellite TV receiver (DTV wireless Genie box)
Power supply for Satellite TV Receiver
Power supply for Sound Bar
Samsung One Connect Mini Port Box
All power and data cables for above

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4 Low Quality

Infill:

30%

Notes:

The 3D printed wall thickness was set to 2mm to make all of the flat elements of the clips solid.

ABS was used for strength and ability to flex enough to clip on the oval shaped horizontal bar.
The OpenSCAD file at the bottom has the element that matches the horizontal bar that the TV is attached to. This piece is then used in each of the clip mount elements.

description.text:
Simple die - printable without wastetower though (sometimes)!

Each layer has sufficient amount of each color, when printing outer walls as last item it means the rest of the inner side of the die can serve as waste - if it is printed big enough and depending on how much you printer oozes or needs to purge.

You can even venture into 3 colors (body, odds and evens)

First 3color version is printable, put slicer needs to manage mesh intersections. "Die2" keeps all nicely separated. I assume printing the 4 or 3 down shall yield best results without prime tower.

Printer:

Geeetech Rostock 301

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I haven't figured out how to align stl's... so here is some input to align the odd and even stl's with the body.
When body is a 19mm cube (as I designed the base cube), then the "even stl" needed an offset (after rotating) of X-1.3775mm and Y+1.3775mm to be in right position.
The "odd stl" required X+1.3775, Y-1.3775 and Z+2.755 (also after rotating).

06/12: Urgh... or do "Select All models" + "Merge models" in Cura.
Also Slic3r has something like "Combine multi-material STL files"

09/12: I got too much color bleeding without primetower (die 19mm), so tried using the default prime tower. Also that doesn't give nice results since all slicers I found only supported 2 colors per layer, so I had to venture into some old school techniques: put an object with 3 colors in your plate and make such that the printing of each color starts on this "PrimeObject".

  • Sorry, still didn't figure out any retract setting that gives good results on my printer :( -

I wasn't satisfied with the design of the original dishwasher wheel mounts for my Electrolux dishwasher when they started to degrade, so I made a few changes and replaced them.
There are two versions available, where the difference is in the number of relief slits, two or four.

Printer:

Anet A8 inspired

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I've used PETG for a slight raise in temperature tolerance compared to PLA.
The locking mechanism is what mainly failed on the original mounts, so they've been re-designed to not have the same type of "flap" as a weak point.

Walls are kept fairly thin to only just retain the appropriate level of rigidity and flexible enough to be able to slide both the wheel onto the mount and the mount onto the dishwasher basket/carriage.
I did have to run several iterations with different print parameters and in the end had to slow down the print speed to 35mm/s and use fairly high hot end temperatures of 235C.

remixed_from.author: ArnieX
remixed_from.title: Ball Lock Keg Connector - all-in-one remix

description.text:
I use this setup to clean my kegerator (keezer) beer lines using an aquarium pump.

The basic idea is to daisy chain your taps and QDs together so you can pump through all the taps at once and recirculate the cleaner.

Note: this only works for perlick-type faucets, if you have a plunger on the front of the tap it will not work and you will make a mess.

I was inspired by the jumper post from Brewhardware.com (https://www.brewhardware.com/product_p/ball_lock_jumperpost.htm).

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Play

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I printed these using PETG but it would probably work fine with PLA as well.
A brim helps to make sure it doesn't break loose when it gets to the higher portion.
The pump adapter does need 'touching buildplate' support for the flange, the other parts do not.
I used the 'spiralize' and 'smooth spiralized contours' settings in Cura, but I am not sure it makes much of a difference.

This was printed on a Printrbot Simple Metal w/ heated bed - the form forced me to select Play for some reason.

Everything needs an o-ring: the ball lock posts at the end, and the pump threads just below the flange (see pictures).

Note that it probably won't make a perfect seal unless you spend a lot of time finishing/sanding. Ain't nobody got time for that, so I used a lot of keg lube on the ball lock posts, and the pump threads, especially around the o-rings. Still a little bit of leakage, but much less than I normally spill on my own :)

You will need:

  • cleaner (I use PBW, then clean water, then Star San .. but for testing I just use water)
  • aquarium pump big enough to pump through all your taps (ie: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B017R708QO is $17 and plenty sufficient for 4)
  • medium sized tub/bucket, etc (I use a ~10l storage tub)
  • BallLockDoubler.stl - one or more depending on how many taps you have
  • Pump-to-BallLock.stl - to screw into the pump
  • Tubing - enough to connect your taps together. I use 1/2" silicon tubing.
  • Clamps? - the silicon tubing seals to the Perlick faucets well enough that clamping is unnecessary.

To clean:

  • First, pour a beer, you will need it later
  • Put the pump and cleaner in the bucket
  • Screw Pump-to-BallLock into the pump
  • Connect the first QD to the ball lock on the pump
  • Use a piece of tubing to jump from one tap to the next
  • Use BallLockDoubler to connect two QD
  • Repeat as necessary
  • Run the last tap or QD back into the reservoir (you can use another BallLockDoubler to keep the QD open). I tend to drain the first bit into a growler until it runs clear so I am not recirculating contaminants.
  • Turn on the pump and drink the beer you poured earlier :)

I let it run for about 15-20 minutes, then flush it with fresh water, then a quick rinse with sanitizer.

I sliced the 'Ball Lock Keg Connector' at the bottom of the ball lock post (using Netfabb) to make BallLockPost.stl.
I then imported that into OpenSCAD and made the rest of the adapters.
The threads for the pump adapters need the Threading library from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1659079

Note that I just guestimated at the threads using a pair of calipers and a few test prints. They work for me, but I am not sure how common those threads are in aquarium pumps.

A small geocache container designed to hang from a tree with a zip-tie. V2.0 sports a knurled base, and is shorter overall, ideal for the 1-1/4 inch width logs. The walls are slightly thicker which makes the inside of both the top and the bottom much cleaner with the slicer I'm using. It allows for two full perimeters on the external and internal walls which eliminated lot's of stray strings inside. V2.1 has several minor improvements including slightly thinner walls. In the wild: http://coord.info/GC50V7J

You may like to print this one using ABS plastic. (PLA is biodegradable)  
Straight out of the printer, the container is not very water-proof, so I used a small paintbrush and some acetone on the outside of the top portion to plug up all the little holes.  This works better than I imagined, and dries back to hard plastic fairly fast.  Make sure your work area is well venerated!  That acetone can be nasty stuff.   
If you have problems with the top half detaching before the print is complete, you can print an extra wide skirt  right up against it.

comments.text: I've had a PLA address plate on my mailbox for a few months now, through a rough winter, and it shows no signs of wear at all.   FYI....

PLA is a corn-based bioplastic.  Some restaurants have PLA cups, which then go in the compost bin. I don't know how long the degrading process is, but it is biodegradable. Also the use for a geocashe is that it might be buried or hung from a tree or in a place where the conditions would be more conducive to degrading.

description.text:
This is a camera mount for the Monoprice Select Mini. it is designed to attach onto the bed tray through snapping over the linear rail. Though not necessary, two M3-0.5 (8mm-12mm long) screws can be used to make the mount more secure.

The mount tabs are 13mm DIA with a 6mm DIA hole for a pin. The tabs are 4mm think with a 5mm gap between (ideal for a 4mm tab to be mounted in the middle).

My goal in making this is to mount a Raspberry Pi Zero W with Zero Spy Camera to run Octoprint for my MP Select Mini. Pi Zero case and arm coming soon.

author: Legacy_Micro

description.text:
These bowls require special processing.
You cannot simply use vase mode because the bottom of the ball part is too shallow and the layers are too far apart, so will sag and or fall out. The trick is to set them up as you would in vase mode, but turn vase mode off, and make the walls 2 layers thick instead of 1 as they would be with vase mode. 2 or 3 bottom layers, and zero top layers.
Additionally I have added easily removable support. See the last photo. One has support that I added and the one on the left has the support removed using small needle nose pliers. You can remove it or not.
Most of these are done with ABS at 245/110C. .26 layers with a .5 nozzle. I usually am too impatient and use .3mm to .38 layers, but this ball issue requires tighter layers.
A simple 2D Christmas Tree ornament design.
Cut on laser

This is a support pin as found on adjustable shelving. Usually when you get a bookcase or some furniture it comes with extra pins. For some reason I can never find those extra pins when I need them.
These printable pins work well as a replacement and they're quite small so you can print a handful of them in an hour. 
These are designed to fit my bookcases and provide a snug fit in the 0.185" holes. The peg diameter as described in the STL file is actually 0.19" which I discovered by experimentation provided the best fit for my printer and shelves.
The image with the blue background is a rendering of the model to give a better perspective on the shape.
I printed these with support at 0.25mm layer height and 100% fill. It's possible that another orientation would allow printing without support, but I haven't tried.

This is an experiment on how to generate random points, connect the lines and apply bezier curves to them.
I hit the limits of opensacd with this because i was unable to reference existing objects in side a function.

The major points that might be interesting is the use of geometry to find the slopes of a line that you don;t know the coordinated of ahead of time. finding perpendicular and parallel points given unknown points.

I heavily use the y = mx +b formula , the distance formula (distance = (y2-y1/x2-x1)) etc.
Then generating based on the slope of the line what points go where.

The open scad file does do the inverse but the customiser times out if you use it so you will have to download the files and compile it yourself

title: QX90 prop guard - reinforced joints - 2.1 grams

description.text:
Prop guard for a QX90 micro quadcopter. May fit other models which are of the same dimensions. Printed in ABS with 100% infill they weighed in at 2.1 grams.

I found other designs to be very good but they kept breaking at the 90 deg joints or added significant weight. These joints have been rounded, hopefully making them stronger. I use only 1 arm per motor which should make the guard less rigid and maybe bend more before breaking. If you end up using this guard let me know if it works out.

description.text:
STILL A WIP as I want to make it thinner and round some edges.

Important: This is sized for my LG D410 aka the Dual-SIM L90. Double-check whether your phone's dimensions are: 131.6mm length, 66mm width, 9.7mm thickness

I removed the hearts from minkgx's L90 case, adjusted the length of the model, and the place and size of the holes on the side, for the volume and on/off buttons, as they were out of place. I did not add an extra hole for the speakers, as I found that using the case, the sound quality actually gets better when facing the screen. With a bit of modeling skill, you can add basically any logo, symbol or similar to the back.

Also do realize that IMO this is a horrible case and you should definitely not use it.

description.text: This is the case for an ATtiny85 based Arduino tracer I have build, it will NOT work on its own. The first version of this project is proof of concept for the electronics, electronics enclosure, and the barrel mounting system. It isn't a very aesthetically pleasing version compared to the tracers on the market today but in V2 when I make a printed circuit board, the size should drop allowing for a round housing. Hopefully this progresses to V2 so I can make kits and possibly make this an open source project with free to use boards, schematics, and a bill or materials.

In need of a better way to store gear in a condo, I fashioned this ski wall mount to hold my bound ski's together on the wall.

Since this is my first published design please share your makes and remixes!

Printed on the Monoprice Select PLUS printed on its side with 4 walls and 10% infill. I did use supports for the overhang of the hollow hook.

author: camolito

title: Small 3mm to 4mm D Knob for Honda Rebel Odometer

description.text:
Ok, this is a quick little thing, but my Honda Rebel's speedometer is missing the odometer knob. I've been meaning to print one since about when I bought the bike, but kept forgetting to do it. Today I had the bike near the printer and remembered!

The picture shows what the stem looks like inside the speedometer.

It's tiny so I used lots of outer layers and infill at .2mm layer height. Printed in ABS. On it's nose it doesn't need supports.

The error in my printer made the spot for the D post a bit tight, and I'm not sure if it was really 3mm, so I made files at other sizes as well, approximately 3.9mm-4.2mm. You may have to print one that fits.

If you like my things, check out my Lego R2-D2.

Full disclosure: Gearbest gave me the CR-10 that I printed this with, so I feel sort of obligated to put it through it's paces.

comments.text: It worked, got to spin it to zero today when I filled up ;)

I love this Filament Shelf (thing 2253244) by asteinmark. As it happens, I put my shelf directly above my 3D printer, so I wanted a way to spool filament to the printer directly off of the shelf. I made this adapter that enables exactly that.

(Note to choose the correct version of the side rails STL to match whether your shelf is based on asteinmark's version D or version C. Use shelf_mountable_spool_holder_for_Version_C.stl if you have Version C, otherwise use shelf_mountable_spool_holder_mashup_v2.stl, which is compatible with Version D. Thanks to yetisnack for catching that both versions are needed.)

You will need 4 standard skate bearings, and 4 8mm x 35mm bolts (with nuts), and 4 medium-size zip-ties.

Assembly instructions:

  • Print 2 each of the appropriate side rails (see note above), and 4 each of the bearing adapters (new-bearing-adapters.stl). 20% fill seems to be plenty strong.
  • For each side rail:
    • Bolt two skate bearings into the two holes provided. Make sure the bearings are against the "inside," (the side with a small hub protruding around the hole). Don't over-tighten.
    • Snap a bearing adapter onto each bearing.
    • Insert two zip ties into the zip-tie slots on the bottom by each circular dowel cut-out. (Note, the zip tie goes in one side, and should snake around and come out on the other side of the dowel cut-out.) Do not close the zip-tie yet, you'll do that once it's mounted on the shelf.
  • Mount the two assembled rails on the shelf, with the bearings facing each other. Tighten the zip ties most of the way, but not super-tight. (Leaving the zip ties a bit loose lets you adjust the distance between the rails, allowing you to accomodate different-sized spools).

comments.text: Thanks for catching that--I didn't originally note that the different versions had different spreads between the dowels. Luckily I had made it in OpenScad so it's pretty straightforward to adjust its dimensions. Try the updated version_C-compatible model I just uploaded (shelf_mountable_spool_holder_for_Version_C.stl) and let me know if it fits better.

title: Laser + Clip Mods for Rubber Band Gun

description.text: A while back, Gavilan posted a design for a really awesome Rubber Band Gun but I thought it was lacking one or two things. So I added a Laser Sight mount (which fits laser pens such as this: Green Laser Pointer ) And an Ammo Clip that can store additional rubber bands. These mods can be easily added to Gavilan's original design. Add just one of them or both!

First print out the Rubber Band Gun by Gavilan (if you haven't already) Laser Sight Mount
Print 2 of the Laser_mount.STL file (No supports, 10% infill)
Attach to barrel using:
  • 1 #6 WingNut
  • 1 #6 Machine Screw 1 1/4"
  • 1 #6 Washer
    Place laser pointer in before tightening wingnut. Rotate laser until button is face up to keep laser on (see pictures)
    • Ammo Clip
    Print 1 each of the Clip_top.STL and Clip_bottom.STL (No supports, 10% infill)
    Attach under base of barrel (see pictures) using:
  • 2 #6 HexNuts
  • 1 #6 LockNut
  • 3 #6 Machine Screws 1 1/4"
  • 5 #6 Washers (1 at the head of each screw and 2 before the LockNut on the back of the bottom screw. )

description.text:
This is the first release in a series of spinning top designs I've created over the last month. There are not many designs on Thingiverse optimized for long spin times and I've been exploring ways to achieve this with typical 3D printers. My first design was beautiful with perfect knurling, but was far from printable :(.

This release, top 2 - long spinner, is designed to be printed in a single piece (with support) and uses a standard BB as the bearing. A major limitation of most printed tops is the poor bearing surface and by improving this contact point spin times are more than doubled. I've exceeded spin times of 4 minutes with this design and I'm sure more is possible.

Next up is top 3 optimized for no support!

title: Tentacles - The slimiest of Greek gods

description.text:
Jointed laser cut octopus tentacles. Plastic green tentacle not included. Moves up and down, and included aglets so you can convert it to motor drive, if you're so inclined. Future goals (if I care):
Alternate stages 180 degrees so that movement is universal.
Fix smaller stage circles clips so that they protrude a little more, properly holding the hinge retainer pieces.

Uses 3mm acrylic.  
Leftmost objects are just the base boolean objects so you can edit everything easier. Don't print those. You'll need one of each of the long parts for every side, print two of each.  
Start with the largest pieces and work your way down. Put the ball in the socket, and clip it to the circle. You could print multiples to make it longer, or shorten the legs and add more to increase the bend.  
Holes are provided if you want to add a string or bowden cable (bike brake cable) for motor control.

title: Aid to the Scales of Justice activity created by Tony Attwood

description.text:
NOTE: Model units are in millimeters
This is a tool that is designed to be used with the Scales of Justice activity by Tony Attwood as described in The complete guide to Asperger's syndrome. As I sometimes struggle with social situations, I use an adapted version of this in my head to reflect on social situations. The Scales of Justice activity can be used to aid people who are on the Autism Spectrum with understanding the outcomes of social situations. This is described below in more depth with a section of the book.

Intended Purpose I intend that this Thing will help people on the spectrum understand certain "Why" 's about social interaction, like why they got suspended or told to stay in during recess time and what they could do in the future when confronted with similar situations. Why I Made This While I was reading the book, I thought that it would be helpful to have had this kind of help and I think that this Thing will make it easier for people on the spectrum to understand some of the things that are confusing to them, such as why they got suspended. This activity may work on regular children from grades K-4.

Step 1 Prepare the materials as listed below. This is intended to be done primarily by the special ed teacher or the child's "observer" (Person who follows the child around to supervise him/her while at school), along with the child. Step 2 Get the child's account of the incident, with events in the order that they happened in, and get the full story as well (historical context, child's observations, and any related incidents), along with any bystanders that may give a helpful, unbiased account. As people on the spectrum tend to be more honest than neurotypical children, their accounts should be relatively accurate. Make sure you have gotten everything that has happened, not just snippets. If the child has a tendency to give inaccurate accounts, be sure to ask for other witnesses, though the people directly involved in the incident should be avoided as they may try to get the child in trouble unless the incident was only an accident. Teachers, recess monitors, and similar "oversight" staff should be avoided as well. Step 3 For each action in the incident the child describes, discuss how many blocks it should be worth. More severe actions correspond to more bocks. The blocks go into the container of the person who committed the act. Step 4 Describe to the child why the outcomes are the way that they are and try to come up with strategies to do better in future situations.

Materials As many containers as the given situation calls for, in any of the sizes or styles to suit your preference, that have been labeled, preferably with removable labels, with the named of everyone involved in the given situation A substantial amount of counters, either the ones included with this Thing or any of your own. Items such as math counters, Connect 4 chips, or coins (for older students, the value of the coin can correspond to their value (U.S. Nickle - 5; U.S. Penny - 1, etc.)) will do.
Containers The containers for each individual person represented should be labeled with the said person's name using Velcro, tape, or magnets.

The Book That Contains a Description of the Activity ISBN: 978-1-84310-669-2
Pages: 103-105
MLA8: Attwood, Tony. The complete guide to Asperger's syndrome. Jessica Kingsley Publishers, 2015.
If you have any legal concerns or advice, please comment on them. I'm not familiar with licensing and copyright policies. The Book's Description " The Scales of Justice activity I developed the ‘Scales of Justice’ activity to help a child who tends to make immature, egocentric or incorrect attributions of the degree of responsibility in situations of conflict, which can include teasing and bullying, between the child and others. Typical children with a developmental level of under nine years tend to attribute the degree of responsibility for an action in terms of who started it, which can appear to justify almost any retaliation, and fail to make an accurate judgement of the severity of their own response and the degree of consequences for themselves and others in making that response. At this stage of cognitive development, conflict resolution can be ‘an eye for an eye’ with the infliction of at least equal, if not more, discomfort.When an adult administers ‘justice’, the response of the child can be that it is not fair, according to his or her perception of responsibility, conflict resolution and retribution. The ‘Scales of Justice’ is an interactive, educational strategy using visual reasoning to help the child understand the degree of importance – the ‘weight’ – given to particular acts and why, ‘on balance’, the ‘weight’ of evidence is used to determine the degree of responsibility and consequences. In English, we may use the comment ‘six of one and half a dozen of the other’ when attributing responsibility for conflict, and this was the comment on which I based this activity. The first stage is to determine who was involved in a particular incident. Each participant has his or her name on a separate piece of paper, and all the named pieces of paper are placed on a table in front of the child. If there are only two participants in the sequence of events, then it is possible to dispense with the names on pieces of paper and actually use a set of scales. The adult has at least 20 wooden or plastic blocks in a container. The number of blocks measures the degree of importance that we attribute to a particular act. A relatively minor infringement of the codes of behaviour may be ‘judged’ as worth one or two blocks while actions that are major transgressions of the code that perhaps could or did result in serious harm or damage would be represented by many more blocks. The child is asked to describe the sequence of events, from his or her perspective. As the story progresses,when a participant in the sequence of events makes a decision to do or say something that breaks the codes of conduct, the child is asked to determine what he or she thinks the words or actions (or lack of actions) are ‘worth’ in terms of the number of blocks. The child may need some guidance with regard to why the number of blocks that he or she attributes to the act may need to be adjusted. This can include information on the effect of the act on a person’s feelings, the degree of potential physical injury and cost of repairing damaged items. When the number of blocks is determined, that number of blocks is placed on the name of the person who did the act. This procedure continues during the recall of the events. Each participant will acquire a number of blocks and, at the end of the description of events, the number of blocks for each participant is calculated by the child. This procedure is designed to enable the child to see the relative importance of what he or she and others did that justified the consequences for all those involved. Perhaps one of the most effective ways of describing the procedure is to provide a summary of how the Scales of Justice activity was used when debriefing a child with Asperger’s syndrome who had a strong feeling of injustice for being suspended from school. There were three participants in the incident: Eric, a child with Asperger’s syndrome, who was 11 years old but whose level of conflict resolution and empathy was [at] least two years behind his chronological age; another child, Steven; and a teacher who was a temporary replacement for the usual class teacher. Steven started the conflict by calling Eric a ‘w***er’ (an obscene expression in Australia). I asked Eric how many blocks that comment was worth and he replied, and we agreed on, a weight of two blocks for Steven. I asked Eric what he did next and he replied that he ignored him. My judgement was that that was the wise thing to do, so no blocks for Eric. I asked him if the teacher (who had overheard the comment about Eric) reprimanded Steven and Eric replied ‘No’ so we agreed that the teacher’s lack of intervention was worthy of one block. Then Steven called Eric a ‘f***ing w***er’ and we agreed that that was worth four blocks. I asked Eric what the teacher did and he replied that the teacher did not hear Steven’s comment, so no blocks for the teacher; but I asked Eric if he told the teacher what Steven had said and he replied ‘No’ so I suggested that Eric should have one block for not reporting the next level of provocation. I then asked Eric what he did when he heard the description of himself and he replied that he said the same words to Steven, so he had four blocks placed on his name. I asked what happened next. Eric described how Steven came up to his desk and scribbled over Eric’s work that he had been doing in class. We agreed that this act was worth two blocks. At this stage, Steven’s piece of paper had eight blocks, Eric’s paper five and the teacher’s one. After the scribbling on his work (which was not seen by the teacher), I asked Eric if he reported the incident, and he replied ‘No,’ so he had another block. I asked what he did next and he described how he hit Steven in the face with his fist as retribution and to make him stop tormenting him. ‘Was there lots of blood?’ ‘Yes.’ ‘Where on his face did you hit him?’ ‘His nose.’ I then explained the degree of potential injury from hitting someone in the face, how painful it would be and the school rules on violence. We agreed that his response was valued at 12 blocks. He could see that although Steven started it, and committed more provocative acts than Eric, by hitting Steven in the face, Eric eventually had 18 blocks, Steven eight, and the teacher one. This was used to explain and to encourage him to accept why he was suspended from school and Steven was not suspended. "

When I was a kid, I had a few of these in my room and it made it really easy to swap posters whenever I wanted. Now that I have kids of my own, and we homeschool, the need for temporarily hanging posters on the wall has only increased. So I went looking online for these and couldn't find them anywhere.

This is a really simple design, powered by gravity. A 1/2" length of 1/4" vinyl tubing is inserted into each clip through the hole on the top. The weight of the poster wedges it and the tubing inside and holds it in place. You can attach them to the wall with either 3M Command strips, or use #4 or #6 screws. (I haven't actually tested the screw-type designs.)

I hope you find this item as useful as we have. It took me several prototypes to get it right, but I think it works great. Enjoy.

title: Chiappa M1-22 Extended Magazine
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE 1-21-18
Well, I found a suitable replacement spring for my extractor. I ended up getting a "rear pin detent spring" off of an AR-15. These springs have a similar diameter, but are stiffer and longer. I simply cut a chunk off that I felt was the right length and then stretched it out a bit and sanded the ends down flat. It's seems to be working perfectly fine for now. You can find these springs almost anywhere. I got mine at a local gun shop for $1, and it's long enough to make 3, or even 4 Chiappa extractor springs out of it. Now back to the extended mag...

The mag seems to work fairly well. I can put in a total of 20 rounds at the moment using two of the stock 10 round springs. You can not however insert the mag while the bolt is closed (there isn't enough spring compression space left after 20 rounds in there). So for now, insert the mag with the bolt open. Second thing, I had a few times where the first couple rounds would nose dive into the base of the breech and cause a jam (the nose wasn't properly aligning with the chamber). I was actually able to remedy this by tightening the mag well set screw in a little bit. Which is weird, I figured I would have to loosen the screw to make the mag fit more snug, but all that did was cause more jams. The mag ran 99% more reliably when I tightened the screw in and ran the mag sloppier. I noticed that the mags are coming out 200-400 microns too small on the body dimensions, (compared to my stock mag). So I'm going to re-size my model and do some testing before I release an updated file. Maybe you can just increase the overall size by .5%? I'm not sure how this would affect the mags performance and reliability though. But overall for an "EXPERIMENTAL" extended mag, I'd say it's working pretty darn good! I'll update again when I get new springs, and redesign the mag slightly for a higher capacity, and possibly better feeding reliability.

UPDATE 12-11-17
I split the model into two pieces so it can be printed more easily on printers with lower z axis ceilings. I was able to squeeze 19 rounds tightly into this mag by using two of the 10 round mag springs butted up against each other. (spring to spring, nothing in between)
It's seems apparent that after doing this that two springs may be just to long for this mag, and a shorter spring would allow another 1-3 rounds. Looks like the mag will hold 23 rounds with some modifications made to the follower, springs, and the spring plug. I was gonna test this mag out for reliability, but I was having extraction issues when dry cycling the rounds. Then I noticed my extractor spring had wiggled its way out and was long gone! That spring is so tiny, I doubt that I'll ever find it. So I can't do any testing until I get a suitable replacement. I made a few changes to the lip I complained about earlier in the middle of the mag, but after I printed mine, everything seemed perfect. No lip, and no problems. I went with 4 shells (a little over-kill) and 3 base and top layers with a 45% honeycomb infill printed in PLA at .100 microns. After doing this I would suggest upping the base and top layer to maybe 5+. Or simply increase your infill %. Once again, I just used the guts from the 10 round mag I have uploaded on thingiverse found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2403229 and you'll have to use supports for under the 3rd lug. I'll update as soon as I get the extractor fixed.

"EXPERIMENTAL" extended magazine for the Chiappa M1-22. I modeled the magazine after the Seymour type III mags. (excluding the holes on the body) I don't really know what the holes were for on the carbine mags. I'm guessing drainage for water and mud. But I left them out of the design for now. Also included is the 3rd lug on the side. Seeing how the M1-22 has the extended arm on the mag release for the 3rd lug, it only seemed right to add it. I have no idea what orientation to print this in. My printer (Flashforge Dreamer) isn't tall enough. So I might have to try printing it on it's back with supports. For the internals, please try using the parts for the 10 round mag I already uploaded. For the spring, you may be able to "double up" two 10 round springs and add a connector in the middle to keep them together. I have no idea how the other parts will interact with this body, and I have no idea how many rounds this thing will truly hold. I'm hoping between 20 and 25. This is why I call it "EXPERIMENTAL". Please comment on your experiences with this mag, I would love to perfect it over time.

NOTE I noticed that where I extended the 10 round mag to make this one, there is a small .08mm lip that "may" cause problems with the follower. This is because the bottom portion of the mag has a different curve in the follower groove than the top does. This had to be done to keep the dimensional accuracy of the M1 Seymour mag. If anyone has a problem with this lip, let me know so I can address it.

title: Barnard S action. Dummy to use to trial fit stocks/chassis

description.text:
This is a dummy action model, only done externally. The Barnard S action is 10mm longer than the Remington700 SA which effects recoil lug placement. So the idea is you can print this and take it along to see if the Barnard will fit the chassis you have in mind.

Note,
Mk1 design will be improved as I get dimensions.
a) External dimensions are accurate as can be 3D drawn based on Barnard's S action CAD PDF (which is missing lots of detail).
b) Some dimensions were scaled off the above drawing so could be / will be in-correct.
c) Internally and the bolt itself this is just guess work as I dont yet have an actual action to measure.

I will repeat this, this is not designed to be machined, its just a model to save you buying the action and then finding it doesnt fit the chassis you want.

PS if you want a seriously accurate gun (like 1/4moa or better Barnard actions should be on your list.

PPS The action is 207mm long so I cut it into 2 pieces so it would fit my Wanhao D6

PPPS The front part of the action and the recoil recoil lug provided will need altering a bit to suit the actual recoil lug you have bought.

Update,
5/12/2017
Added Jewel trigger and Barnard S hanger parts to assist trail fit.
Modded rear body to accept trigger hanger

Update2
I talked to KRG and the Barnard S action will probably fit but there is a clear clearance issue with the action to rear trigger hanger area, machining mods needed in this area. Also there should be enough metal upfront to stand machining for the extra length of the S.

Update3
11/2/2018
I talked to Magpul about their new pro 700 stock and they tell me there is not enough metal to remove to make the S action fit.

title: CR-10 S Bowden Drive with guide and filament sensing

description.text:
CR-10 S Upgraded Bowden Drive with Z-Screw Guide, and filament out sensing screw.

Instead of the filament sensor being strung out on the filament and not guiding it around the screw correctly, this incorporates the Z-Screw filament guide, as well as the sensor / switch that informs the printer that filament has run out.

description.text:
Here are two different versions of holders for 4.5 ounce epoxy bottles. I made three different styles of each version so you can hold 2, 4, or 6 bottles.

I build a lot of balsa and foam planes, and therefore use epoxy quite often. I keep three different "speeds", 5 minute, 15 minute, and 30 minute. With so many different bottles I wanted a way to organize them a bit, so I came up with "Version 1" of my 4.5 ounce bottle holder, designed to hold the bottles right-side-up. After looking at other designs that held them upside-down I changed my design (Version 2) to allow for that as well. Keeping the bottles upside down means you won't have to wait for thick epoxy to eventually squeeze out of the bottle. When held upside down the tip of the bottle is resting on the base, which should help keep the tip from falling off. The base is also designed with a lip around it just in case you have a major spill it won't end up on your work bench.

Note on "Version 2", when you glue the base to the top some clamps may be useful to keep it all lined up. In the picture of mine you can see that they aren't lined up very well due to my error in assembly.

title: Wanhao D6/MakerSelect Ultimate Silicone Boot for heat block

description.text:
This is a simple cutting apart of a very nice design for a silicon high temperature 'boot' to shield the 3D printer heat block from excessive fan cooling which can lead to failed prints.

A picture has been posted of a way to use just the central piece and manually make the required boot and avoid having to buy and make the custom goop as seen in the thing I mention below. So my boot looks rather rough but works very well.

You can lightly coat the central piece that looks like the heat block with Vaseline for a release agent to remove the dried silicone then apply 1st coat and let dry for 2 hours. Next apply 2nd coat to fill in any gaps or very thin parts and also to smooth out the surface with a Popsicle stick or other flat tool.

Please see thing 1817230 for official credit for this part. This is just a split to the 3 pieces.

title: Edge lit acrylic sign with printed base

description.text:
These are some Edge lit signs i have designed along with a neat little 3d printed base to house the electronics. The base is a clam shell design and the legs snap on. You will need a 12v power supply with a 2.1mm barrel jack connector to power this bad boy.

I use cast acrylic, cut on a CNC router for the sign portion. You can etch, engrave or sandblast any clear plastic and it should work, but cast acrylic is very easy to work with.

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01LZUUH3K/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 Here is the LED strip i used. Its pretty standard weather resistant 4 pin PWM RGB strip. You can use whatever, but the cutout is sized for the weather resistant stuff.

https://www.ebay.com/itm/5-PCS-Mini-3-Key-Controller-Dimmer-Amplifier-For-RGB-5050-3528-LED-Light-Strip/192221834182?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649 These are the controllers i use. Inexpensive and you dont have a stupid remote to lose. the cutout in the sign base should expose the buttons on the controller. I use hotglue to secure this inside the base.

https://solarbotics.com/product/swt15/ Here is a 2.1mm barrel jack plug with integrated rocker switch I found. It goes along way for making the base look legit. Should just press right into the base. Solder the controller leads directly to the paralell terminals.

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B072KRCJLD/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 These connectors are not essential, but they make life alot easier. I cut them in half and solder a tiny peice of 22ga solid wire on each end. The 22ga solid wire plugs in nicely to the controller. I use hotglue to secure the wires once the controller is installed.

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00GDXW3OE/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 These self threading screws go through both halfs of the sign base and the acrlyc sheet, locking everything in place.

comments.text: This is excellent! I've been itching to try some edge lit signs on my MPCNC with either an endmill on the router or 2.8w laser attachment. This looks like just the ticket for a nice professional looking base to get me motivated. From what I can tell from the dxf samples this is for 6" wide by 1/4" acrylic. Would it be possible for you to add a 12" wide version as well? I've attempted to modify the STEP via Fusion360 but my CAD skills are lacking.

This is a simple alternative to the stock Y belt clips.
People use anything from a bare bolt to multipart belt tensioner with success. Mine is a step up from a bare bolt. It has more support while still being quite light.
I have an original plastic bot not an LC.

Slic3r does strange things to this stl and throws in solid layers where there should be holes. I drilled the hole to 2.5mm and tapped to M3. I didn't tap all the way but got a screw though OK.
I use .4 layers and PLA. With this as well as the standard X belt it is much easier to put the belt on if you use locking forceps to hold it in place while zip-tying.
The hole needs to move a little.
I drilled new holes about 4mm inboard from the existing outer holes.
In other words the holes on the side closest to the motor (right) are a bit too close.
Of course these are sized to fit my printer and may need modification for others. FYI the top of my Y belt sits 15.5mm below the bed.

location of wires where to solder input of led controler. Ground wire (black) is solder on the main plug of the board (easy to remove the plug and the cable to solder on top) 12V wire is solder on the main 12V from the back of the switch. Thus i don't need to switch on the printer to get the led on, i can control the led without switching on the printer. Again easy access to the wire, no cut needed. Red and black wires soldered to the input of led controler soldering cables from the output of led controler to both led support. Soldering instructions

Solder the input of led controler to the black wire (taken on the plug of the card) and the red wire (taken on the switch. You can easily remove both wires to solder a cable here and then put them back in place (no need to cut any wire).
Then solder black and red onto the same cable for both the 2 leds supports as shown on the draw.

I needed a new desk fan at work, was just getting into Fusion 360 and had a spare 70mm computer fan and 12 volt transformer lying around; so what to do, make a bladeless fan of course. This fan is really easy to print and assemble, the soldering of wires is about as difficult as it gets.

Assembly:

  1. Mount the computer fan inside the base on top of it's support.
  2. Feed wires through hole in support.
  3. Solder fan and transformer wires to a switch (I bought a basic switch from my local electronics store).
  4. Insert the Fan Inner into the Fan Outer, no gluing required, should snap in place and hold.
  5. Insert the Fan Inner/Outer into the base. --Too easy!

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Fan Outer:
Needed support everywhere.

Fan Inner:
Printed with support everywhere, but I think it will be fine without supports.

Fan Base:
Print upside down with supports touching build plate only.

description.text:
This is a simple Bookstand ; a type leaning against the wall.
So, we need a wall to lean on, such as a reading room desk or a monitor.
It's simple but can keep books stable with two paper presser foot.
the additional presser foot end for a thin book is optional.

You need m3x25 cap screw and Hexagonal nut(2 pcs) or pointed screws are also fine.
To prevent slipping, I used glue on the floor. You may attach a rubber or non-slip pad to the floor. (Place the stand over the wet surface before the hot melt glue is firm, and the plane becomes flat)

I printed it to 2mm shell thick and 0% filling with PLA.

This is a actually two distinct designs for a 3D printed fishing rod mount to mount onto a wheelchair.

It was created over a weekend as art of the TOM Tikkum Olam Makers Makeathon in Melbourne 2017.

The straight tube mount is useful if the chair already has a tube at 45 degrees that you mount directly on. if not the other assembly will work well but may need to be padded out.

The design requires M6 or quarter inch HEX bolts of appropriate length to work. You may need to resize the knobs if the HEX bolts do not grip properly.

Happy printing and making the world a better place

A general tablet, which should be compatible with most tablets. I made mine specifically for an iPad 3. I hope to give it more functionality in the future, such as having a holder for a stylus or keyboard.

Printing

All parts should be printable without supports if oriented correctly. I split the body up into several parts, because i have small printer. There are three main parts:

  • Part A
  • Part B
  • Part C
    To connect each part a dowel should be inserted in the holes with glue. PartA is the "bottom part", Part B is the"elongation" and Part C is the actual "arm" which holds the tablet. This process should be repeated with partA(1), partB(1) etc.. The two plates can now be glued into place at their designated cut-outs.
Finishing

As an idea you could print something personal, such as logo or text, and glue on the plates to give the stand some personality. Furthermore you could spray-paint the stand in a specific color to make it look even better. If you really want to make it look nice, you could do the whole sand-prime-fill-sand process.

This thing a remix of kittka's "Yamato style Spaceship".

The change I made (other than moving over to the Thingiverse) was breaking apart the hull pieces to make it easier to print. I don't have nearly a big enough printer to print the pieces it was broken into. Now you can print the lower hull in red and the rest in silver to make finishing it that much easier. I also added a stand (borrowed from another model I can't find anymore to attribute) with a UNCF logo you can glue on. I left the tail section as one piece so that there's a sturdy piece to hold it all together. Also included a pin model to print to use on the cannons so that they can be swiveled.

One recommendation is that you print the side gun turret mounts -0.88 mm sunk into your build platform to remove the unnecessary raft the original designer put on there.

title: Punchdown Stand for Legrand On-Q WP3475/WP3476 RJ45 Keystone Jacks

description.text:
This is a punchdown holder or stand for the Legrand On-Q RJ45 keystone jacks, part numbers WP3475(cat5e) and WP3476(cat6). The main advantage of using the holder instead of just setting the keystone on a flat surface is that the holder includes a recessed channel to hold the cable in place during punchdown. This assumes you'll have the cable laying sideways to the connector for punchdown, as shown in the Legrand instructions.

The design was inspired by the Keystone Jack Punchdown Holder by rssalerno. The terminal block orientation of the Legrand On-Q jacks is very different from the Leviton and Cable Matters jacks used by rssalerno, however. This design reuses rssalerno's minkowski approach to form the rounded edge base, but little else.

The main parameter a user may want to tweak is the diameter of the cable being used. The provided STL is configured for my 6.0mm OD CAT6 UTP cable. Cable can be inserted either by pressing it down into the shaped channel or sliding it in from the end.

Top level geometry options are provided for creating the printable base and for previewing an RJ45 jack inserted into the base.

title: Cherry Popper - Mechanical Keyboard Switch Opening Tool
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A tool to speed up opening of Cherry MX mechanical keyboard switches and similar clones. Makes keyboard modding a lot easier, especially when lubing or switching springs.

This is a redesign of the original found here http://kbdlab.co.kr/index.php?mid=board_etc&search_target=nick_name&search_keyword=%EC%95%84%EC%B9%A8%EC%97%90%E2%84%A2&document_srl=101589.

I found the original design printed in PLA would break after opening 30 or so switches. This redesigned one is strengthen and I was to open and disassemble 200 switches without it breaking.

As usual this wont work on switches soldered to a plate, but works with loose switches.

description.text: Exploded Sphere with various length extrusions. Sphere is textured as well.

Thanks to sneakypoo for the original and the effort expended to create it. I needed something larger to hold a standard gift card, and this is the result. The upscale factor in x and y is 2.6x with some reduction in the z direction. Original creator's size is 23 mm inside diameter, while this one is about 60 mm inside diameter. It's pretty darn big when it's done, but holds the cards easily. There's room for a quantity of gift cards or as I did, a card and a 3D printed trinket. When the gift card is used up, it's a pencil holder (2) or other caddy for the desk. Hide your candies in it and keep prying fingers from getting to your stash.

description.text:
Light and slim set of landing leg extensions for DJI F450 style quadcopter arms. These were designed around a set of cheap Chinese knockoff arms, so I can't say they will fit true DJI arms correctly.

They're probably not going to fare too well in a heavy impact since I designed them to be low profile and relatively light, but they'll give you approximately 110mm of extra ground clearance to sling a gimbal with a GoPro under the quad.

UPDATE 12/3/17: Previously uploaded '450_leg_lock' file was not mirrored as required. I've re-exported and re-uploaded the .stl with the correct orientation.

description.text:
This is a customized open cable chain based on Claghorn's design here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:611593

Increased cable chain size 20% to allow more wires to fit inside. I run a Titan Aero and have a CiiCooler and BLTouch on my extruder assembly. With all these wires, a typic 20mm cable chain is very tight.

I also didn't like having to remove my connections on the end of wires in order to fish them through the cable chain.

Claghorn's design has an interlocking spring that covers the cables, enclosing them inside the chain.

Included is the mount for the side of the printer, as well as a mount that fits on the standard D-Bot X Gantry.

12/3/17 Update:
Seperated the extruder and frame mounts into separate files.
Fixed a weak part on the extruder mount where the spring clips in.
Added single Spring file
Added single Chain file
